International Alert is an NGO based in London with field office in Uganda that works to preventing armed conflict and strengthening human security in over 25 countries and territories and influencing decisions and policy orientation at regional and international level. International Alert sees as its mission to work together with people in conflict-affected or risk areas to influence developments towards peace, that on a regional and international levels to improve policies and policy compliance are important for creating peace, and to strengthen other actors in peace building.
International Alert in Uganda has been developing innovative private sector approaches to peace building in Uganda with support from the Swedish Embassy since 2005. Alert began this “Business for Peace” (B4P) programme by developing guidelines for conflict-sensitive development sector interventions and researching whether and how the Ugandan business community could be mobilised for peace.
The main objectives of this new phase of the B4P project is to; - Strengthen the level and nature of interactions between business associations, civil society organisations and government institutions in creation of a peaceful business environment. - Improve knowledge and understanding of civil society organisations on the connection between conflict-sensitive business practices and peace in Uganda. - Enhance the capacity of business associations in identification, mediation and resolution of business-related conflicts - Promote and monitor use of gender and conflict-sensitive business practices, policies and regulations among business associations, government institutions and civil society
To achieve the above objectives, International Alert will work with the private sector including business associations, civil society organisations and government institutions.
The project will be implemented in 3 years (2016-2018) with a total budget of SEK 18 000 000. The Embassy assess this project to contribute to the achievement of the results strategy most specifically as one that addresses conflict issues directly. The Embassy therefore proposes that Sweden enters into agreement to support International Alert Uganda for a period of 3 years 2016-2018, with a total amount of 18 000 000 SEK

International Alert är en London-baserad NGO med fältkontor i Uganda. De arbetar med att förhindra väpnade konflikter och att stärka mänsklig säkerhet i över 25 länder och territorier. International Alert arbetar med påverkansarbete på både regional och internationell nivå och har som syfte att arbeta tillsammans med människor i konfliktdrabbade riskområden för att påverka fredsbevarandet. För att skapa fred och stärka de aktörer som arbetar med fredsbevarande är det viktigt att på både regional och internationell nivå förbättra policyer och se till så att de efterföljs. International Alert fyller en viktig funktion i detta arbete.
International Alert i Uganda har utvecklat innovativa insatser inom den privata sektorn för fredsbevarande i Uganda, med stöd från Sveriges Ambassad sedan 2005. Organisationen startade programmet "Business for Peace" (B4P) och utvecklade riktlinjer för konfliktkänsliga interventioner inom utvecklingssektorn och studerade huruvida det ugandiska näringslivet kunde mobiliseras för att skapa fred.
De huvudsakliga målen för den nya fasen av B4P programmet är att: - Stärka nivån av samarbete mellan företag, civilsamhällsorganisationer och statliga institutioner för att skapa ett fredligare företagsklimat.
- Stärkt förståelse och kunskapsökning för CSO:s om relationer mellan konfliktkänsligt näringsliv och fred i Uganda.
- Stärkt kapacitet för näringslivet att identifiera, medla och förhindra affärsrelaterade konflikter.
- Främja och kontrollera användandet av genderkänsliga och konfliktkänsligt näringsliv, policyer och regleringar för företag, statliga institutioner och civilsamhället.
För att uppnå ovannämnda mål kommer International Alert att arbeta med den privata sektorn inklusive företag, civilsamhällsorganisationer samt statliga institutioner.
Projektet kommer att pågå under 3 år (2016-2018) och den totala budgeten är 18 000 000 SEK. Ambassaden i Kampala bedömer att projektet bidrar till den av regeringen beslutade resultatstrategin för Uganda. Ambassaden föreslår att Sverige tecknar ett avtal för att stödja International Alert Uganda under 3 år (2016-2018) med en total budget på 18 000 000 SEK.

description.narrative: The programme was running from March 2016 to February 2017 when it was suspended due to suspected mismanagement of funds. During the year of implementation International Alert still managed to carry out a number of activities and reach some results. According to the reporting, the project has strengthened relationships, discussions and enhanced capacity among boundary partners that has contributed to promotion of a peaceful business environment. This has been done through training, dialogues, awareness-raising events, conferences and other planning and consultative meetings to reach a common understanding on gender and conflict-sensitive business practices, and conflict prevention and mitigation. International Alert offered tailored trainings to specific key actors on conflict mediation and resolution, which has allowed them to manage conflicts at a local level and preventing them from escalating. For example, as a result of the training on conflict sensitive business practices and mediation skills, which has led to the use of mediation in the resolution of conflicts. International Alert gives a number of examples of successful mediation efforts in their final report. International Alert also report on “significant improvement” in coordination and actions by business associations towards promoting a peaceful business environment. One specific area mentioned is on the topic of the impact of violent extremism on business and what role they can play in mitigating root causes of violent extremist acts. According to International Alert, this debate has been unique, since initiatives aimed at preventing or countering violent extremism are often very state-centric and considered an issue of national security. However, this excludes any analysis of the wider impact of violent extremism on societal dynamics, including the impact on business. One of the most common contributing factors cited as motivating some young people to join violent extremist groups is unemployment and lack of opportunity to contribute to their society. International Alert, through this project, has sought to expand the debate and discussion around this in major cities like Kampala, and engage the business community in this analysis. In terms of strengthening participation in policy processes, the project created spaces for key stakeholders, including the business community, to contribute to preventing and mitigating conflicts related to poor policy formulation and/or implementation. For example in 2016, research was conducted in Kampala, Jinja, Mbale, Lira, Arua and Kasese to map urban conflict1. The findings of this report identified specific drivers of conflict that businesses, market authorities and government ministries should take account of in their activities in order to contribute to a resolution of these tensions, for example the importance of inclusive recruitment practices, and adopting a consultative approach to urban planning and design (for example in market places). These messages were conveyed to decision makers at both the district and national levels through regional policy meetings which highlighted the importance of a participatory approach to designing and communicating policy. Such dialogues have also helped to bring together business and government to address emerging tensions between the government and the private sector in relation to the implementation of the policies. A multi-stakeholder dialogue meeting on “Uganda and South Sudan Business Community Trade Relations” was convened by KACITA and International Alert. The meeting, which involved 62 participants from business associations and individual business people and stakeholders from Uganda and South Sudan, including the South Sudan Embassy in Kampala, highlighted a number of key impacts that the conflict in South Sudan is having on regional trade, and the possible knock-on effects for social cohesion between trading communities. As a result of the workshop, a series of recommendations were drawn up on how to alleviate the negative effects of the conflict on the business community and keep interaction between businesses on both sides going. This dialogue highlighted the specific risks faced by certain groups of vulnerable women and children who have been caught up in the conflict in South Sudan, for example widowed or single mother traders whose businesses have been affected. In order to explore this further and develop specific policy recommendations to put to regional dialogue efforts, Alert in partnership with UNCCI and Northern Uganda Business Forum for Peace (NUBFP), organised a one-day conference with 63 women refugees from South Sudan, community leaders, technical policy experts and decision makers. The conference was unique in the sense that it gave women refugees the opportunity to discuss and amplify their voices on the multifaceted challenges they have faced.
